title: Templecombe and the Shroud of Turin (Continued)
post:
Thank-you for the article. I am a Historian and Author, who has studied and written about the Templecombe panel. I have also had two recent visits by Rex Morgan, who has assisted me with all his research papers, including lab results of particulate samples taken from between the grooves of the Templecombe panel by his collegue Dr E. Nitowski, which provided some very interesting results. 
The Carbon 14 dating for this artifact is between 1280 and 1340. It now hangs in a special exhibition room at the Bishops Palace, Wells, Somerset.
Are you also aware that another ‘head’ exists? It is from Temple Cloud Somerset. This head is wooden, and carved in relief. It has recently been Carbon 14 dated, and is of almost identical date to the Templecombe panel. The chuch where it was found was in the possesion of the Knights Templar.
I would argue that there is a strong possibility that this is another example of a Templar ‘Idol’, or as Dr Frale would say ‘Simulacra’. 
All this, including Dr Nitowski’s findings, and Rex Morgan’s research are included in my latest book ‘Glastonbury, the Templars and the Sovran Cloth’ published by the History Press 2012.
   Juliet Faith

title: Templecombe and the Shroud of Turin (Continued)
post:
Dr Gowlett of the Oxford Radiocarbon Excelerator Unit (ORAU) examined the samples, and his conclusion was that the wood was cut between 1280 and 1310 plus or minus 60 years. He added that the wood was cut in the early Mediaeval period.
Obviously there is no way at present to prove when the image was painted, he observed that it could be as late as 1440, however during the Mediaeval period wood was usually used ‘in the green’.
I agree that the head could be Hospitaller, but in view of the accusations of heresy levelled at the Templars for ‘worshipping’ a disembodied bearded head, one may consider it a little foolhardy of the Hospitallers to paint an image that could invite accusations of the very same?
author: Juliet Faith

title: Templecombe and the Shroud of Turin (Continued)
post:
Radiocarbon results are given as 95% confidence intervals. You have to quote the whole interval, not just its early years. This result was published by the Oxford AMS laboratory in their paper:
Archaeometry, volume 29, issue 2, August 1987, pp. 289–306
Radiocarbon dates from the Oxford AMS System: Archaeometry Datelist 6
R.E.M. Hedges, R.A. Housley, I.A. Law, C. Perry and J.A.J. Gowlett
I quote from p. 303:
<<Templecombe. Two samples taken from the edges of two planks of a door with a Shroud-like image of Christ. The door was found on the site of a former Templar preceptory at Templecombe in Somerset (Wilson 1986). The dating was requested by C. Watson of TV South-West.
<<OxA-1042 Wood from plank I: 580 ± 60.
<<OxA-1043 Wood from plank 2: 580 ± 60.
<>
But it is not important to discuss about the dating of the panel. The important point is that there is absolutely no evidence that the Templars owned or had ever seen the Shroud (much the less that the Shroud had ever been in England) and there is not any resemblance between the Templecombe portrait and the Shroud, apart from the fact that both have beard and long hair (beard and long hair were a common feature of men of those times).
As to the thesis of Barbara Frale, she has been severely criticized by historians in Italy. Suffice it to say that she read a passage in a manuscript as “signum fustanium” while the words were clearly written as “signum fusteum” (“fusteum” = made of wood).
PS: “Accelerator”, not Excelerator.
author: Gian Marco Rinaldi

The medieval Latin phrase,  in figura baffometti used to identify/describe the mysterious head venerated by the Knight Templars can be rendered in old French “en semblance de baphomet” (in English “in likeness of baphomet”). 
  According to me, the Latin baffometus that can be trancripted in French baffomet/baphomet, comes from the medieval Hebrew phrase ba-pheo-emet, “in his mouth is the Truth”. This can allude at one and the same time to Yeshua as “la Bocca della Verità” (see Revelation), the already famous “Bocca della Verità” in Rome (literally “the Mouth of Truth” in Italian, an ancient stone mask from the Classical period that represents the river god Okeanos  with an open mouth, wide eyes and a flowing mane of hair much like both Yeshua’s  Holy Face of the Veronica Veil (also in Rome) and that of the Holy Face of the Holy Hemation/Sindon (i.e. Yeshua’s burial Sindon kept “tetradiplon” within a wooden reliquary-table or monstrance so as to leave only the face visible through a vast circular central opening on front side). The true visual fact is both the Holy Face of the Holy Veronica (now in kept in Manoppelo) once combined with the Holy Face of te Holy Shroud/Sindon does look like the terrifying mask of La Bocca della Verità in Rome. 
  Now both the Greek word Sindon and the medieval Latin Signum can be translated  Synne/Sydoine in old French and specifically refer to Yeshua’s burial cloth. Hence, in the medieval ms, the Latin phrase “signum fusteum” can mean in old French “synne le bois (de la Croix), “(Yeshua’s) burial cloth/sign of the wood (of the Cross)”) or could even be the short for “signum fuste(n)um” (mistranslation/misunderstanding) and translate the old French “synne de fusteine”, in English (“Yeshua’s) fustian burial cloth”.”Fustian” was a medieval fabric that consisted of linen and wool woven together and dyed (the word “fustian” comes from Al-Fusṭāṭ, an ancient city south of medieval Cairo, Egypt and could refer to a medieval eastern fabric).

If an image of the Cameley head is overlaid on the Templecombe panel painting it matches almost exactly. It is a life sized head which would origially have been painted, with wide open eyes an open mouth, long hair and a forked beard, it also has a trellis frame or border often seen in examples of the Manylion.
 The C.14 dating of this head, which was recently undertaken by the Oxford lab dates it between C.1280 – 1341, it is made of oak.
It was found in a Templar church, and local tradition says it is Templar.
If another identification can be made I am prepared to be pursuaded! 
For now though it seems to fit the picture of  the Templar idol. I refer again Dr Frales comments on the ‘cult of the Simulacra’  a cult which was introduced to Britain by the Templars and emerged in Britain ‘in the late 1200’s.
